text: Okay, the tape is rolling. In Ménage Autre... Ménage Autre. Ménage Autre, sorry about that. Okay, I'll say it. In Ménage Autre, Jason Ward, the hero, attends an autograph session, and he didn't seem to have very much fun there. Did this arise out of real-life experiences, or are most of them a little more fun than that? Oh, I love autograph sessions. I love it. But it's easy to take it and, you know, if you were tired or you wanted to be somewhere else, I've never had the experience of having an endless group of people coming up and demanding my autograph, you know. I go to autograph sessions that I've been to. We figure if eight or 12 people come, everybody's very delighted. it. I know that some mainstream authors I have read about get very unhappy at autograph sessions. They get tired. When you read about the American Booksellers Association Convention, usually they say that the science fiction authors were among the most agreeable there who just kept signing autographs and signing autographs and other people got really upset and cranky and so forth and so on. So it's easy to make up. And we've all had experiences when we were doing something that we wish we were some slight self. So it's easy to take the situation and invent it. Whereas as we're sitting there and signing good luck and best of wishes, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera, and asking them, how do you spell your name? That I've been through. I've learned that you always ask the person how to spell their name because sometimes they spell it in very different ways. And I've met authors who could think of very witty, very original things to write in every book, but I'd freeze up. I'm glad to sign my name, but I can't be creative there on the spur of the moment, so I usually end up saying good luck, best wishes, best ever, and do that repeatedly. So that part was realistic. Why are science fiction authors so accessible to the fans, Whereas, as you mentioned, in other genres, they're not. I have no idea. I don't know. I don't know if it's science fiction people are writing because they love it. I would think that most writers write because they love it. But I just really don't know. Maybe it's because more than science fiction people have a chance to know their fans on a first-name basis. They meet them at conventions. They get in the habit of socializing with the people that are reading their books. And other big-name authors maybe don't have that opportunity. I just really don't know. I'd like to ask you a couple of questions now, just on the general nature of science fiction. Are those who now claim that there's a glut of fantasy which is appearing and that this glut of fantasy is appearing to the detriment of science fiction. Do you have any observations on this pro or con? There's a lot of fantasy, I agree. I don't know that it's to the detriment of science fiction. I think there's certainly room for both. I think both fulfill needs of people. I keep telling mundane kind of people, mainstream kind of people, who ask about, what do I purpose, or what good is science fiction? And I keep saying, well, people have always wanted myths. They have always wanted wonderful creatures. They sit around the campfire and they would fantasize about the creatures that lived in the next country. Well, this whole planet, we know what's in the next country on this planet. The monsters are in outer space, or the myths can be in outer space. They're also in inner space. It's the same reason that I think the vampires and horror stories have come up because that's where people can go to for myths now. I don't know what it is in people that want these wonderful monsters, but they will have them. They don't care if the world is settled. Why, if they'll go back to the old-fashioned ones that sneak around, the things that might exist, people that want to reach out can reach out for strange and wonderful creatures beyond space and the ones that don't want to reach out can reach for the creatures in inner space I think it also has to do with a lot of the time um the space that things are very complex they're very frightening there are no clear cut rights and wrongs and there's really no answers to lots of problems. One answer, what answers one problem, raises a whole lot more problems. Everything's so interlinked. You raise employment and you do this and that, and some of that's detrimental and so forth. And I think fantasy is, I don't want to say it's an escape. I don't want to put it down. I don't read fantasy because maybe it's because I like to reach out. Maybe it's because I'm a little more optimistic. I believe there will be a tomorrow. But I think people read fantasy because they can get away from all the grays. Fantasy provides worlds where there are clear rights and clear wrongs where you can end their problems with a strong right arm and a magic sword and a pure heart. And I think that the heroic fantasy then gives people something to get away from, to get away from this world, like a lot of these movies that they were producing during the Depression and a lot of the books that they were writing during the Depression, adventure stories, so the people could get away from the terrible things that they had to face every day. And I think that's why there's a lot of fantasy. And I think there's a need for it. And I think it's wonderful that it's there for the people who want it. And there's probably a lot of bad fantasy written and a lot of junk fantasy. But heaven, you go on the mainstream shelves and there's certainly a lot of junk there. And I think that the work that is well written and the work that is good will probably manage to sustain itself even as the junk comes and goes and passes away. My engineer wants me to ask a question. Hang on a second. What question? Ask her if she thinks that might have some sort of tie-in with the boom and the fantasy role play again. Okay. Okay. Do you think this has some sort of tie-in with the boom in the fantasy role-playing games? I think that they're both part and parcel of the same thing. People who can play roles in fantasy games are being more actively involved in the fantasy than just sitting there and reading it. They're living it, in a sense. and again it's a way to to be faced with problems that have clear solutions and rights and wrongs to them I think probably the upsurge and the fantasy that people were reading came before the roleplaying but I think it's all part of the same thing in a way it discourages I can't say it's really discouraging But I think it reflects a certain pessimism, perhaps, about the future. Perhaps, as I said, perhaps that's why I still like science fiction, why that's what I write and that's what I read, because I retain a certain optimism that somehow, maybe not grandly or gloriously, people will survive. I think we will perhaps even prevail, will at least will limp along into the next century, and the century after that, and the century after that. That's kind of what happens in my books. You may have noticed that there are a lot of large social problems that exist within each book that never get solved, but people in the book solve their own problems. They handle their own lives. And I think maybe that a little bit of personal philosophy of mine come through that I can't solve the world's problems, but I can certainly keep control of my own life. And my belief in that I can pass on. Which authors, writing now, do you enjoy, just out of curiosity? Oh, a lot of them. I read a lot. Always between books. I sit down and read 40 or 50 of the stretch because they pile up on my shelf. I like Joseph Wombaum. I have enjoyed Lewis Thomas, who did Medusa and the Snail and Lies to Sell. I enjoy Isaac Asimov. I enjoy Anne McCaffrey and a lot of Jalary Niven and C.J. Cherry, not all of Fred Saberhagen, but certainly a lot of his work, Just glancing at some of H.B. Piper Tannis Lee She writes fantasy And I do read some of hers I've discovered a writer Who's now dead, unfortunately Van Gulick Who wrote a bunch of mysteries About a 7th century Chinese Magistrate, Judge D And I've started collecting his books Chelsea Quinn Yarborough I enjoy there are a lot of books a lot of authors I like I'm rather Catholic in my reading tastes I read a lot of non-fiction as well as fiction science books, sociology books This is just a trivia fact it's not anything to the interview you mentioned Lewis Thomas I have a friend who lives in Connecticut who's working on an MBA and in one of his business ethics courses they had to read both the Lewis Thomas books which you wouldn't expect in a business course. It's a little unexpected, yeah. But it's encouraging. The other great question I wanted to ask you, there are those that are bothered by a seemingly recent trend in that everybody is writing prequels and sequels. In fact, the Hugo Awards, all the novels nominated were either prequels or sequels. Some people are bothered by this, other people don't care. Do you have any feelings on this? Well, I started out thinking that I was going to write each one different, and I may still end up doing a lot of that, you know, creating, rebuilding the world anew each time I write a book. It's certainly easy if you already have the background there, and in a sense, it's no worse than mainstream writers who are writing all out of the same world, aren't they, and yet they get infinite stories out of the one particular world. I think the readers, what's the word? They like continuity. Mystery writers, mystery readers, have liked reading the same characters forever and ever. I mean, how many continual mystery characters are there? There are detectives. Mystery is replete with series characters. And why do you think people watch series television? Because they like to see these same characters over and over and over again. They get hooked on a character. I suppose it can be a little discouraging to think, well, gee, they're not after any new ideas. They're just after these one characters, who if they're in a series, they can't really change because you have to keep them the same or they're not the same characters anymore. Oh, dear. We're getting a buzz. You hear a buzz? Yeah. Okay, we don't hear it over here, so apparently it's not getting on the tape. Oh, okay. Okay, go ahead. Continue if you want. and it's all about it can be financially rewarding to have a series because people like a particular character then you know you've got an audience every time you write a book about that particular character it'd be nice if each of the award-winning books was something that stood on itself instead of being parts in a series. And maybe award-winning books should be. But certainly, the things that are voted by the fans, like the Hugos, are the things that they want to read. And while I think a writer should necessarily pander to public taste, if he wants to make a living, you've certainly got to write something that people want to read. And if he has engaging characters and people like them, why not write about them? I've got people hounding me to write more Mama Maxwell and Jana Brill, and I have no objections to doing that. They're a good pair of characters to make a series, because they don't have to change from book to book. On the other hand, the book I'm writing now carries within it the seats for a sequel, but it wouldn't have the same characters in it. It would simply be more of the story further on down the line. I can't really blame readers for liking series books. If they liked this particular book why they want more of the same. And I can't blame writers who want to make a living for giving them more of the same. And I can't blame readers for buying it and reading it. I don't know that it's any kind of a degeneration in literature. Those books may last. They may not. I think a writer is an entertainer. A writer is an entertainer. And if he thinks that he's creating deathless prose with every line he struggles to put down, And if he's writing for history, then he's probably got pretension of brand dexter. If I write a book that people buy and read by buying, they give me my money, which I need, and if they enjoy it by reading it, then I'm really happy. I don't think I would write a book just for money, but certainly I want to write something that is fun for me to write and I want to write something that is fun for readers to read. Okay, David, you have a question. Now the engineer wants to ask you a question himself. Okay. Can you hear me all right? Yes. Okay, my question is about writing and writing technique. When you start writing a story, do you develop your characters first or the storyline first? Which comes first and which follows, and how does it progress into the full-blown story? It's sometimes one way and sometimes the other. Sometimes I have a character. I'm trying to think of one in which I had a character first. I know I have, but I have had others where there was the story idea, and then I searched in that idea for the character who was most affected so that I could have that character at the center. Sometimes I make mistakes. I was six chapters into the book I'm writing right now before I realized that one of the characters I had as protagonist didn't know a whole lot of things, that it would increase tension if the audience knew. Therefore, I went back. I had a character who just sort of wanted on the page. He was going to be a bit character. But I was interested in him, and I thought I'm going to do a book about him eventually. Then it occurred to me that he knew the kind of things that would be interesting for the readers to know, so I went back and made him the other protagonist for the book. But other times, I've had a character that I was interested in. Oh, yeah, House Divided, the woman who was a split personality. I had her first and had worked out her character, and then I found a situation to put her in. So sometimes it works one way and sometimes it works the other. Sometimes I have a setting, and I have a beautiful setting, then I have to figure out a story and characters to go with it. And I think stories start all kinds of ways. Okay. That's my list of questions. Okay. Let's see. It's almost an hour and 15 minutes, my goodness. Okay, I'll become a fan again. And yeah, I love the Mama Maxwell and Jana Brill stories, and I would hope to see them again. The reason I wanted to talk to you, I just kind of accidentally stumbled on you when the first novel came out. And bang, bang, bang, here came four novels, and they've all been very good and very enjoyable, and so that's the reason I wanted to talk to you. Plus you seemed very accessible at the con. so we appreciate getting to talk to you. I hope, I'm glad you liked it. That's why I'd say writer's entertainer and if people don't enjoy reading my stuff that I fail somewhere along the line no matter how artistic the book might be. I'm definitely going to do more with Molly Maxwell and Jana Brill. I was going to do them next but I had this sequel idea for this other book and I think maybe it'll be next. Let's see. I had something... Your statement about writers being entertainers, I have a feeling that's going to be one of the shows. That's too good to pass up. That when you were getting to the end of that, that was, I think, quite revelatory. And I agree, I just never had thought of it that way. Just like baseball players? Sure. Football players? Sure. You'll have to go on strike so you can become a free agent or whatever. Absolutely. Unfortunately, the publishers have the best because there are a lot of people who want to be writers. And so the competition is fierce. Yeah, I would think so. It would be nice if, as an entertainer, I could pull down the same kind of salary that a football entertainer pulls down, for instance. You know, it's one of these days, maybe I'll get a bestseller. That's what I'm working for. You have to know what's important in life. And obviously, football is... It's even more important than the president the United States now. I wouldn't be the president of the United States. It's a no-win situation. Uh, that's for sure. David, any more questions? No, tell her this will probably be edited within two months and we'll be sending her copy tapes of the air program. Okay, fine. We'll send you a copy of the interview and then we'll also edit it within the end. No, no. No, we'll send her a copy tape of the program. Well, yeah. I was going to get to that. And then we will send you copies of the edited programs for your enjoyment. I love hearing them. Okay. Sure appreciate your talking to us. We enjoyed it. And keep on writing. We're out here and we read it and would like to see some more. Well, I've got about six more chapters of this book to go, which I've got to get done by the 1st of March. It is. You have it in by the 1st of April. You'll find out what happened to those columns. I would like to know. is this, are you going to, are most of your books going to appear paperback-first, or hardback-first editions on down the line for writers? I've never really understood how that works. It's a lot easier to get published in paperback because, let's face it, hardback is expensive, and people are much more likely to put out $2.25 or $2.50 for something that looks interesting and that they might like. I think they're going to have to be sure they're going to want it before they're going to put out $10 or $12 for it. The mass-market media is a paperback and it's much easier for it to get published in paperback and it's certainly easier to get your name spread around that way. I think later perhaps, my agent is trying for some hardback edition and I would love to have stuff picked up by the Science Fiction Book Club. but it hasn't happened yet I have some story ideas and proposals into my agent that she's trying for hardback she has a vampire novel of mine that she's trying for hardback but I have a feeling that when it comes out it'll probably come out in paperback is it a vampire mystery novel? it's a vampire cop mystery novel a vampire police procedure novel okay because one of the vampires in it is a cop mmhmm and he's he's another unusual he's about and he's blonde and gray-eyed and he's Irish-American. He's a little different than your normal vampire. You've got the corner on the market on police procedure novels and they are enjoyable so you might as well throw in at everything. Engineer has another question yes. What sort of mythos are you using on the vampires can you go out into daylight? Okay. Which of the vampire mythoses, whatever the plural is, are you using? Can he go out in the day? Oh, yes. I picked up most of the things straight out of Dracula. I went ahead and used that. Except, he goes out in the daytime, but he feels miserable. He hates it. He can subsist on any blood as long as it's blood. Crosses don't bother him because he wasn't particularly religious growing up. but he quits breathing in the presence of garlic. It's like all the air in his lungs turn to concrete. He can't go in where he isn't invited, which he finds a distinct handicap in the police officer. He can go through walls. Now, I might have to rewrite that. There was one point at which he goes through a solid wall. Every place else he went through, like doors and so forth, which he could have gone. and he didn't really know how he went through. He just knew he did. He didn't examine the procedure too closely because he didn't like being a vampire and didn't really wanna get to know the whole thing too well. Let's see what are some of the other things. Disproportionate strength? Disproportionate strength, is that what you said? Oh, it's quite strong. Superhuman strength nothing. Very disproportionate strength, very strong sense of smell and very strong hearing. And I wrote the book to be as realistic as possible. Of course, the reader knows right away, practically, that there's a vampire involved before our cop gets bit and becomes a vampire. But he doesn't even catch on that she's a vampire when she's biting him. He thinks she's really weird. Because I try to think, what would a normal, everyday person think? A person's glommed onto their throne that way. You know, and even when he's in the hospital and he's miserable in the daylight and he feels much better at night and he's throwing up food and his front teeth are coming loose and things like that, he has to sit there and watch the Friday Night movies and watch Dracula on the movie before he starts to catch on what's going on, you know? Did you, you mentioned Saberhagen. Did you read his, or enjoy his Dracula novel? Very much. I have all Chelsea Quinn Yarborough's, too, but I haven't managed to read them yet. They're sitting on the shelf waiting. I understand they're quite good. I haven't read them yet, either. I have, I guess she's bringing out a fifth. I have four of them, and they're fifth in the series, which is a modern-day one, I guess. But I've enjoyed the Fred Saborhagen books very, very much. And there's a couple of other vampire ones that have been, oh, let's see, Kenneth Lee had one that wasn't very enjoyable. Sabella? Was that Sabella? Yeah. Yeah. Mm-hmm. And there were a couple of others I read that weren't all that terrific. But, yeah, I find vampires very fascinating. I've also got the Vampire Tapestry, which is on my reading shelf, too. If the cop can carry warrants through the wall, I guess that would be quite a plus for him. If he can carry... Carry once. Oh. I don't know if he could do that or not. Presumably his clothes would go with him, but I don't know about papers. See his, I don't think I ever had him carrying a solid object through. At the point to which he was going through and carrying solid objects, it was like a mesh gate or something. That was when he was carrying a thermos bottle so he could fill it up with blood and take it home until he'd have a couple of days' supply and wouldn't have to hunt all the time. If that doesn't make Hardback, will that be a Del Rey book and come out in a science fiction package? no, unfortunately it won't be a Del Rey because I was under contract to write that book and once it was turned in, they turned it down because Judy Lynn really isn't a fantasy editor and I don't know why she wanted why she thought she wanted the book she was explaining why she turned it down and it sounded to me like her image of a vampire is the Hollywood image, where they have to sleep underground in a coffin at night, and can't go out in the daylight at all. It sounded like she hadn't read any of the recent vampire books, and she probably didn't sound like she'd read Dracula either, because Dracula went out in the daylight. In fact, the more blood he drank, the better he felt. He was out there running around in the daylight perfectly well, and he just couldn't change shape and things like that in the daylight. Oh, my guy's not a shape-changer breather, and he does reflect in a mirror. That makes it hard to shave if he can, according to the engineer. That's true, yeah. Somebody teased him once. What was it? Oh, he was saying he was allergic to garlic. Somebody says, oh, how long have you been a vampire? At which point he started to freak out, and then he realized that they were just teasing him. They asked him something about shaving, and he said, well, the electric razor was a great boon to vampires. Okay. The engineer uses an electric razor, so he appreciates that, he says. It's been very nice talking to you. Thanks again. And we look forward to seeing what's coming out, and you'll hear from us with a little package of tapes one of these days. Okay, you bet. Bye-bye now. Well alright here.

segments.text: Okay, the tape is rolling.
In Ménage Autre...
Ménage Autre.
Ménage Autre, sorry about that.
Okay, I'll say it.
In Ménage Autre, Jason Ward, the hero,
attends an autograph session,
and he didn't seem to have very much fun there.
Did this arise out of real-life experiences,
or are most of them a little more fun than that?
Oh, I love autograph sessions.
I love it.
But it's easy to take it and, you know, if you were tired
or you wanted to be somewhere else,
I've never had the experience of having an endless group of people
coming up and demanding my autograph, you know.
I go to autograph sessions that I've been to.
We figure if eight or 12 people come, everybody's very delighted.
it. I know that some mainstream authors I have read about get very unhappy at autograph
sessions. They get tired. When you read about the American Booksellers Association Convention,
usually they say that the science fiction authors were among the most agreeable there
who just kept signing autographs and signing autographs and other people got really upset
and cranky and so forth and so on.
So it's easy to make up.
And we've all had experiences when we were doing something
that we wish we were some slight self.
So it's easy to take the situation and invent it.
Whereas as we're sitting there and signing good luck
and best of wishes, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera,
and asking them, how do you spell your name?
That I've been through.
I've learned that you always ask the person
how to spell their name
because sometimes they spell it in very different ways.
And I've met authors who could think of very witty,
very original things to write in every book,
but I'd freeze up.
I'm glad to sign my name,
but I can't be creative there on the spur of the moment,
so I usually end up saying good luck, best wishes, best ever,
and do that repeatedly.
So that part was realistic.
Why are science fiction authors so accessible to the fans,
Whereas, as you mentioned, in other genres, they're not.
I have no idea.
I don't know.
I don't know if it's science fiction people are writing because they love it.
I would think that most writers write because they love it.
But I just really don't know.
Maybe it's because more than science fiction people
have a chance to know their fans on a first-name basis.
They meet them at conventions.
They get in the habit of socializing with the people that are reading their books.
And other big-name authors maybe don't have that opportunity.
I just really don't know.
I'd like to ask you a couple of questions now,
just on the general nature of science fiction.
Are those who now claim that there's a glut of fantasy which is appearing
and that this glut of fantasy is appearing to the detriment of science fiction.
Do you have any observations on this pro or con?
There's a lot of fantasy, I agree.
I don't know that it's to the detriment of science fiction.
I think there's certainly room for both.
I think both fulfill needs of people.
I keep telling mundane kind of people, mainstream kind of people,
who ask about, what do I purpose, or what good is science fiction?
And I keep saying, well, people have always wanted myths.
They have always wanted wonderful creatures.
They sit around the campfire and they would fantasize about the creatures that lived in the next country.
Well, this whole planet, we know what's in the next country on this planet.
The monsters are in outer space, or the myths can be in outer space.
They're also in inner space.
It's the same reason that I think the vampires and horror stories have come up
because that's where people can go to for myths now.
I don't know what it is in people that want these wonderful monsters,
but they will have them.
They don't care if the world is settled.
Why, if they'll go back to the old-fashioned ones that sneak around,
the things that might exist,
people that want to reach out
can reach out
for strange and wonderful creatures
beyond space
and the ones that don't want to reach out
can reach for the creatures
in inner space
I think it also has to do with
a lot of the time
um
the space that things are very complex
they're very frightening
there are no
clear cut rights and wrongs
and there's really no answers to lots of problems.
One answer, what answers one problem, raises a whole lot more problems.
Everything's so interlinked.
You raise employment and you do this and that,
and some of that's detrimental and so forth.
And I think fantasy is, I don't want to say it's an escape.
I don't want to put it down.
I don't read fantasy because maybe it's because I like to reach out.
Maybe it's because I'm a little more optimistic.
I believe there will be a tomorrow.
But I think people read fantasy because they can get away from all the grays.
Fantasy provides worlds where there are clear rights and clear wrongs
where you can end their problems with a strong right arm and a magic sword and a pure heart.
And I think that the heroic fantasy then gives people something to get away from,
to get away from this world, like a lot of these movies that they were producing during the Depression
and a lot of the books that they were writing during the Depression, adventure stories,
so the people could get away from the terrible things that they had to face every day.
And I think that's why there's a lot of fantasy.
And I think there's a need for it.
And I think it's wonderful that it's there for the people who want it.
And there's probably a lot of bad fantasy written and a lot of junk fantasy.
But heaven, you go on the mainstream shelves and there's certainly a lot of junk there.
And I think that the work that is well written and the work that is good will probably manage
to sustain itself even as the junk comes and goes and passes away.
My engineer wants me to ask a question.
Hang on a second.
What question?
Ask her if she thinks that might have some sort of tie-in with the boom and the fantasy role play again.
Okay.
Okay. Do you think this has some sort of tie-in with the boom in the fantasy role-playing games?
I think that they're both part and parcel of the same thing.
People who can play roles in fantasy games are being more actively involved in the fantasy than just sitting there and reading it.
They're living it, in a sense.
and again it's a way to
to be faced with problems
that have clear solutions
and rights and wrongs to them
I think probably the upsurge
and the fantasy that people were reading
came before the roleplaying
but I think it's all part of the same thing
in a way it discourages
I can't say it's really discouraging
But I think it reflects a certain pessimism, perhaps, about the future.
Perhaps, as I said, perhaps that's why I still like science fiction,
why that's what I write and that's what I read,
because I retain a certain optimism that somehow,
maybe not grandly or gloriously, people will survive.
I think we will perhaps even prevail,
will at least will limp along into the next century, and the century after that, and the
century after that. That's kind of what happens in my books. You may have noticed that there
are a lot of large social problems that exist within each book that never get solved, but
people in the book solve their own problems. They handle their own lives. And I think maybe
that a little bit of personal philosophy of mine come through that I can't solve the world's
problems, but I can certainly keep control of my own life. And my belief in that I can pass on.
Which authors, writing now, do you enjoy, just out of curiosity?
Oh, a lot of them. I read a lot. Always between books. I sit down and read 40 or 50 of the stretch
because they pile up on my shelf.
I like Joseph Wombaum.
I have enjoyed Lewis Thomas,
who did Medusa and the Snail and Lies to Sell.
I enjoy Isaac Asimov.
I enjoy Anne McCaffrey and a lot of Jalary Niven
and C.J. Cherry,
not all of Fred Saberhagen,
but certainly a lot of his work,
Just glancing at some of H.B. Piper
Tannis Lee
She writes fantasy
And I do read some of hers
I've discovered a writer
Who's now dead, unfortunately
Van Gulick
Who wrote a bunch of mysteries
About a 7th century Chinese
Magistrate, Judge D
And I've started collecting his books
Chelsea Quinn Yarborough
I enjoy
there are a lot of books a lot of authors I like
I'm rather Catholic in my reading tastes
I read a lot of non-fiction as well as fiction
science books, sociology books
This is just a trivia fact
it's not anything to the interview
you mentioned Lewis Thomas
I have a friend who lives in Connecticut
who's working on an MBA
and in one of his business ethics courses
they had to read both the Lewis Thomas books
which you wouldn't expect in a business course.
It's a little unexpected, yeah.
But it's encouraging.
The other great question I wanted to ask you,
there are those that are bothered by a seemingly recent trend
in that everybody is writing prequels and sequels.
In fact, the Hugo Awards, all the novels nominated were either prequels or sequels.
Some people are bothered by this, other people don't care.
Do you have any feelings on this?
Well, I started out thinking that I was going to write each one different,
